title: Quantitative in vivo assessment of amyloid-beta phagocytic capacity in an Alzheimer’s disease mouse model
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
In vivo labeling of amyloid plaques
Timing: 3 h
This section describes how to label amyloid plaques with methoxy-X04 (MeX04), a blood–brain barrier-penetrating amyloid-beta (Aβ) dye. After MeX04 is intraperitoneally injected into Alzheimer’s disease (AD) transgenic mice, it enters the brain and binds to the surface of Aβ plaques. If microglia are actively phagocytosing amyloid plaques, MeX04 will be internalized together with Aβ. Thus, subsequent flow cytometry analysis enables the quantification of the capacity of microglia to phagocytose Aβ within the 3 h interval between MeX04 injection and sacrifice.
Intraperitoneal injection of MeX04 into 6–18-month-old AD transgenic mice
Warm the MeX04 working solution (2 mg/mL) in a 37°C water bath for 5 min before injection.
Weigh the AD transgenic mice and intraperitoneally inject MeX04 working solution at 10 mg/kg.
Note: Also include non-transgenic wild-type (WT) mice (i.e., without amyloid plaques) to control for MeX04 signal baseline in flow cytometry analysis.
Brain dissociation and microglia isolation
Timing: 3–4 h
This section describes a modified protocol to maximize the number of microglia isolated.
Critical: To achieve a high yield of viable microglia, freshly prepared aCSF with pH 7.2–7.4 and gentle mechanical dissociation are essential. It is also recommended that each experimenter handle fewer than 3 samples to minimize differences in digestion time.
Brain dissection
Euthanize mice using isoflurane 3 h after MeX04 injection and perfuse mice with 20 mL ice-cold PBS.
Dissect the region(s) of interest in ice-cold PBS.
Brain dissociation by papain
Prepare enzyme dissociation solution by adding 0.004 g l-cysteine, 100 U papain, and 700 U DNaseI into 20 mL working aCSF solution (refer to “Materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]” for detailed recipe).
Prewarm the enzyme dissociation solution in a 37°C water bath for 5 min.

Mince the brain tissue into small pieces on a petri dish and transfer to a 50-mL falcon tube with 20 mL enzyme dissociation solution.
Incubate in a 37°C water bath with constant shaking for 10 min.
Remove the tube from the water bath and let the undigested tissue sink to the bottom.
Very gently pass the tissue through a 20-gauge needles 3 times and return the tubes to the 37°C water bath for an additional 30 min of digestion.
Pellet the cells by centrifugation at 800 × g at 4°C for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and subject it to a Percoll gradient.
Percoll gradient
Prepare isotonic Percoll by adding 9 parts Percoll into 1 part 10× HBSS.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 7 mL working aCSF solution.
Add 3 mL isotonic Percoll and mix well by inverting 10 times; the resultant solution contains 30% Percoll.
Gently add 2 mL working aCSF on top.
Centrifuge at 800 × g at 4°C for 15 min with the slowest acceleration and zero deceleration.
Use a P1000 pipette to gently remove the myelin debris layer trapped between the aCSF and 30% Percoll, and subsequently aspirate all supernatant (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).

Figure 1. Photograph of the myelin layer and cell pellet after Percoll gradient centrifugation
The myelin layer is trapped between the 30% Percoll layer and artificial cerebrospinal fluid layer.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 200 μL of ice-cold DMEM/F12 with 10% heat-inactivated FBS.
Cell staining
Before cell staining, aliquot 5 μL cell suspension and inspect cell viability, number, and singlet by hemocytometer.
Note: Number of viable cell number ranges from 1.5–3.0 × 106 per forebrain depending on age of AD transgenic mice.

To label microglia, stain the cell suspension (200 μL) with CD11b-APC (1:200) and CD45-FITC (1:200) for 45 min at 4°C with rotation. In addition, prepare unstained controls using AD transgenic model mice and non-transgenic wild-type mice to serve as fluorescence-minus-one controls.
Note: The emission spectrum of MeX04 overlaps with that of DAPI/Pacific blue.
After 45 min, wash the cells with 1 mL DMEM/F12 + 10% FBS and centrifuge at 800 × g at 4°C for 5 min.
Resuspend the cells in 500 μL DMEM/F12 + 10% FBS.
Flow cytometry
Switch on the flow cytometer and perform machine start-up.
Create the following plots in the template (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A and 2B)

Figure 2. Gating strategy and analysis of Aβ phagocytic microglia in APP/PS1 transgenic mice
(A) Gating strategy to identify CD11b+ CD45lo microglia. SSC, side-scattered.
(B) Contour plots showing the proportion of Aβ phagocytic microglia in 16-month-old APP/PS1 mice (an Alzheimer’s disease transgenic mouse model). Age-matched non-transgenic wild-type (WT) mice, which lack MeX04 signal, are used as control.
(C) Histogram showing the MeX04 signal intensity of Aβ phagocytic microglia (i.e., MeX04+ microglia) and non-Aβ phagocytic microglia (i.e., MeX04− microglia). MFI, mean fluorescence intensity.
Side-scattered (SSC) versus forward-scattered (FSC) (to identify cell populations)
Pulse width trigger versus FSC (to identify singlets)
PB488 versus FSC-A (to identify CD45 signal)
PB660 versus FSC-A (to identify CD11b signal)
PB450 versus PB660 (to identify MeX04 signal)
Use a non-transgenic mice brain sample to set a negative signal for MeX04 and an unstained control sample to set a negative signal for CD11b and CD45.
Proceed with the samples and record the MeX04 signals of 10,000 microglia.
Analyze the data using FlowJo to obtain the following:
Proportion of MeX04+ microglia = proportion of Aβ phagocytic microglia (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B)
Mean fluorescence intensity of MeX04 = Aβ phagocytic capacity (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C)
